detail.content: Creative Writing Program | New York University                      NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                                                                            Home       Faculty       Undergraduate Program       Graduate Program       Low-Residency MFA Writers Workshop in Paris       Summer Programs & Courses       Reading Series       Literary Journals       History of the Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House       Donate to the Creative Writing Program       Alumni News & Publications         “Great books are books that have two authors, the reader and the writer.”   Jonathan Safran Foer           The NYU Creative Writing Program, among the most distinguished programs in the country, is a leading national center for the study of writing and literature. The undergraduate and graduate programs provide students with an opportunity to develop their craft while working closely with some of the finest poets and novelists writing today. The Creative Writing Program now occupies a lovely townhouse on West 10th Street in the same Greenwich Village neighborhood where so many writers have lived and worked. The Lillian Vernon Creative Writers House allows writers--established and emerging--to share their work in an inspiring setting. We invite you to join a supportive and serious community of writers engaged in an exceptional program of study. Documentary Fictions: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Undergraduate Film & Television Admissions About the Program Course Offerings Summer Courses Showcase Internships Facilities Special Projects First Run & Festivals Calendar of Events News TSOA FTV Wiki Admin & Faculty Alumni Blog Facebook Twitter YouTube  home > Undergraduate Film & TV        Documentary Fictions  H56.1207 Lecture 3 Credits This course will explore the blurred boundaries between documentary and fiction filmmaking which have always been there from the very birth of cinema and are a major conceptual force in the cutting edge films of today. Intended to widen the horizons of the creative filmmaker, we will analyze documentary traditions with a specific focus on the narrative techniques used in the telling of powerful stories. Alongside, we will examine contemporary fiction films that have broken new grounds by a creative absorption and sometimes exploitation of the documentary method. These include films that deliberately confound fact and fiction, include improvisations, dramatic reconstructions and are occasionally downright mock-docs. We will examine the "truth claims" and "reality principles" of a wide-ranging, eclectic body of international cinema, both fiction and documentary, and in doing so, will recast the definition of 'documentary' today.
